questions.question_text: A company is conducting a project that is expected to have positive effects on a local town. The townspeople are excited about the project and want to help make it a success, but they are nervous because updates have not been released for a while. Which of the following explains how the project manager can ensure the project is a success?

A new stakeholder has joined the project team and requested modifications that will result in minor changes to the project budget and schedule.
The project manager is concerned that the requests will lead to:

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Hi, change control board, the customer wants something else added…. again! The goal is to avoid
another scope term called scope creep.
Scope creep is unauthorized or uncontrollable changes to the scope of work without any
regard to scheduling or budgeting. It’s the project management equivalent of having too
many cooks in the kitchen trying to make soup. Everybody decides to walk by the pot and
add salt to the soup. It isn’t going to take awfully long before the soup is ruined.
every time the question states "minor changes" it becomes a hint for scope creep
I think the answer is A, because when there are changes to schedule and cost, there are concerns about the effects on quality.

discussion.content:

comments.content:
looking back on this confronting is not practical here. It will cause more issues:

In a situation where one team member is disrupting the work of others by listening to loud music, it may be appropriate for the team to try to find a solution through negotiation. This could involve discussing the issue with the team member who is causing the disruption, explaining how their behavior is affecting the team, and working together to find a mutually acceptable solution. This approach allows the team to address the issue in a collaborative and respectful way, and may be more likely to lead to a lasting resolution than more confrontational or authoritarian approaches.

Confronting the team member who is causing the disruption could potentially escalate the situation and create animosity within the team. Smoothing involves minimizing or downplaying the importance of the issue, which may not be an effective way to address the problem. Forcing the team member to stop listening to loud music may not be a sustainable solution, and could lead to resentment or conflict within the team.
